Award.AbstractNarration:
PROPOSAL NUMBER: 0801536
INSTITUTION: Case Western Reserve
NSF PROGRAM: PHY - PARTICLE ASTROPHYSICS
PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR: Akerib, Daniel S.

TITLE: Astroparticle Detection

ABSTRACT

Observations of galaxies, superclusters, distant supernovae and the cosmic microwave background radiation tell us that about 85% of the matter in the universe is not made of ordinary particles, but exists in some dark form. Deciphering the nature of this dark matter is of fundamental importance to cosmology, astrophysics, and high-energy particle physics. A leading hypothesis is that it is comprised of Weakly Interacting Massive Particles, or WIMPs, that were produced moments after the Big Bang. If WIMPs are the dark matter, then their presence in our Milky Way may be detectable via scattering from atomic nuclei in a terrestrial detector.

This proposal requests continued base-program support to work on the Cryogenic Dark Matter Search (CDMS) experiment which, in conjunction with the initial funding of the SuperCDMS project grant, will allow for (a) the completion of the CDMS-II experiment, which is fully constructed and acquiring science data at the Soudan Mine, (b) the testing and underground operation in the CDMS-II infrastructure at Soudan of two new ?SuperTowers,? each comprised of six next-generation detectors, and (c) a modest effort of long-range R&D to develop and test new hardware and detectors for possible followup experiments.

This program will have broader impact than the WIMP search results. The technical development will push the envelope of phonon-mediated detectors, which have increasing applications in astrophysics, from optical astronomy to x-rays and cosmic microwave backgrounds studies, as well as other branches of physics such as quantum computing. In addition, the SuperCDMS collaboration will continue its support of public outreach program at Soudan, which hosts thousands of visitors each year for tours of the mine and laboratory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our research is aimed at resolving the 80-year-old cosmological mystery of “dark matter.”  If Newton and Einstein’s theory of gravity holds true on galactic and cosmological scales, then we have a serious problem: 80% of the matter in the universe has not yet been directly observed in telescopes. It has only been inferred from its gravitation effects on visible stars and galaxies. Further deepening the mystery is that this dark matter must be composed of some new form of matter not yet seen in nature. There is simply not enough ordinary matter (protons, neutrons, etc.) to account for this missing stuff. Our group at Case Western Reserve University with support from the National Science Foundation has participated in two different approaches to detecting this mysterious substance.

 

Specifically, we are testing the hypothesis that dark matter is composed of Weakly Interacting Massive Particles, or WIMPs. These particles may have been produced in the Big Bang and represent most of the matter in the Milky Way. Using ultrasensitive particle detectors installed in underground caverns to shield them from ordinary cosmic radiation (“cosmic rays”), we look for evidence of collisions between WIMPs and the atomic nuclei that make up the detectors. In the Soudan Mine in Northern Minnesota, as members of the Cryogenic Dark Matter Search, we operated ultra-cold crystals of germanium and silicon in a shielded refrigerator just above absolute zero. By operating these detectors for several years we were able to place new world-best limits on the size of these WIMPs. While an observation would have been incredibly exciting and groundbreaking, even the non-observations we have made help to rule out specific types of particle theories that could account for WIMPs. Some of these candidates are close cousins of the particles that high-energy physicists are trying to produce and study at Large Hadron Collider in Geneva. A detection there would inform our, and vice versa.

 

To further improve the sensitivity to WIMPs, in 2008 our group joined a new project, the Large Underground Xenon experiment, or LUX, which is building a next generation detector based on liquid xenon with an active mass that will be more than twenty times larger than the germanium/silicon array. This new detector is being installed in the Homestake Mine in South Dakota and will begin data taking towards the end of 2012.

 

Our group participated in prototyping and building the cryogenic systems used to liquefy and circulate xenon in the detector, as well as many diagnostic and control systems. These were successfully operated this past year in a surface laboratory set up near the mine.  Our group is also working on an purification step to remove radioactive krypton that is present in xenon from the time it is collected from the atmosphere. The radioactive decays of the krypton, if unchecked, would mask the signal from WIMPs. We are now completing the final installation of the detector in the mine and the purification of the xenon in our lab at Case.  In the coming months, we hope to begin taking data on what we expect will become the world’s most sensitive new WIMP detector in 2013.
